posts.name: Michael Jansen
posts.cooked: The device under test is undergoing its early stages of development, with images capturing its progress from various angles. The first image shows a close-up of a team member inspecting the device, followed by a discussion of the system layout, mentioning a 4GB RAM configuration and the presence of an RGB backlight. The second section reveals a detailed view of the front panel, highlighting components like a display module and a 3D printed aluminum heatsink for thermal management. Further images delve into internal workings, showcasing the placement of a 4GB RAM module, a CPU socket, and various circuit boards, both assembled and in disassembly. Additional photos illustrate the device's build process, including the installation of a Wi-Fi antenna, the use of adhesive tabs on a plastic board, and a complete 3D printed enclosure made of aluminum. The final images cover different sections of the device, emphasizing its technical specifications, component assembly, and overall construction quality.

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked: The assistant has effectively streamlined the text by eliminating all HTML tags, resulting in a concise and clear version that retains the original intent.

Overall, it looks fantasticIm really looking forward to this! My only concern, however, relates to the design: How do they handle the heat? The RPi 5 doesnt have heatsinking, and from my experience, it can get quite hot when running closed-case vision detection pipelines. Would you mind sharing insights on typical temperatures from alpha teams, particularly if they underclock the Pis to manage heat?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: The RPi 5 design includes an anodized aluminum bottom case that is thermally connected to the system-on-chip, serving as an effective passive heatsink for managing heat during vision processing tasks.
Oh, oops. I overlooked that. I thought it was made of nylon from the first picture. It would make a good heatsink.

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked: Maybe I missed it when the specs were posted, but I'm curious as all get out why there is a WiFi/BT antenna connected via a USB port on the CM5.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: SystemCore includes WiFi, as FIRST Tech Challenge will need it. FIRST Tech Challenge doesn't use an external radio.

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked: That makes perfect sense. Thank you.

posts.name: Patrick McNaughton
posts.cooked: The compute module is the 4GB RAM configuration, excited to have more than 512 MB of memory.

posts.name: Graham Howard
posts.cooked: The screen is driven off of a RP2350. Theres a handy utility built into the OS that flashes said RP2350 on boot with a uf2 also in the OS. Theres a project that will run Doom on a 2350 and similar LCD screen. The CM5 image is now available here.

posts.name: Patrick McNaughton
posts.cooked: The CM5 image is now available here. Release Limelight SYSTEMCORE Release 157 (STABLE) 路 LimelightVision/systemcore-os-public 路 GitHub. Does this mean we will be able to upgrade the compute module to one with 8 or 16 GB of memory? I dont remember the rules on COTS electronics modification.

posts.name: Graham Howard
posts.cooked: I assume itll be up to the 2027 rules.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: downloads.limelightvision.io provides specifications for systemcore_specifications_june15_2025_alpha.pdf, which is 731.57 KB in size and features a logo for downloads.limelightvision.io. This document appears to detail specifications for SystemCore Testing, including information relevant to Alpha and Beta testing phases for SystemCore and MotionCore devices. Additionally, GitHub hosts a related repository for further details on this topic.

link_counts.title: GitHub - wpilibsuite/SystemCoreTesting: Repository for Alpha and Beta testing of SystemCore and MotionCore devices

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: The LINK port enables cross-platform connectivity over USB-C. This is an alternative interface to the Ethernet and Wi-Fi interfaces. If the LINK port is attached to a device at boot time, Systemcore enters flash mode for recovery OS updates. Wait, does this mean if I want to tether to the robot via USB, I have to unplug USB every time I turn on the robot? Enabling CANivore Support...

posts.name: M
posts.cooked: Does that mean we can run doom on system core and play bad apple on the screen?

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked: A concerning absence of magnetometer specifications on the IMU section raises questionswere they simply overlooked, or does the device fundamentally lack such components?

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: Yes.

posts.name: Dan Nichols
posts.cooked: I really like the DIO being 24 V tolerant as well as the section about debris mitigation. I wonder if the 5GHz access point mode will work for FRC FIRST Robotics Competition at-home testing. Weve certainly gotten in situations where we didnt plan ahead and were stuck struggling with 2.4 on the VH-109.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: The FTC sized fields are tuned for FRC teams, who typically bury their controller inside the robot. This might not offer significant improvement over the 2.4 GHz 109 model, but experimenting could still prove beneficial.
